This theorem states that for every positive number 'x' and another number 'y' greater than one, there exists an integer 'n' such that 'x' lies in the interval between 'y' raised to the power of 'n' and 'y' raised to the power of 'n+1'. This interval is open on the left (meaning it does not include 'y' to the power 'n') and closed on the right (meaning it does include 'y' to the power 'n+1'). The theorem applies under the conditions that the type 'Œ±' is a linear ordered semifield, is Archimedean, and supports the operation of addition for elements less than or equal to each other.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemifield Œ±] [inst_1 : Archimedean Œ±] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE Œ±] {x y : Œ±},
  0 < x ‚Üí 1 < y ‚Üí ‚àÉ n, x ‚àà Set.Ioc (y ^ n) (y ^ (n + 1))
name: exists_mem_Ioc_zpow
docString: This theorem states that for every positive number 'x' and another number 'y' greater than one, there exists an integer 'n' such that 'x' lies in the interval between 'y' raised to the power of 'n' and 'y' raised to the power of 'n+1'. This interval is open on the left (meaning it does not include 'y' to the power 'n') and closed on the right (meaning it does include 'y' to the power 'n+1'). The theorem applies under the conditions that the type 'Œ±' is a linear ordered semifield, is Archimedean, and supports the operation of addition for elements less than or equal to each other.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ‚Ñï` with `y ^ n < x`.

docString: For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ‚Ñï` with `y ^ n < x`.

This theorem states that for any type `Œ±` that is a commutative monoid, the "divides" relation (`x` divides `x_1`) is equivalent to the "less than or equal to" relation (`x` is less than or equal to `x_1`). In other words, for any two elements in a commutative monoid, saying that one element divides the other is the same as saying that the one element is less than or equal to the other.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : CommMonoid Œ±], (fun x x_1 => x ‚à£ x_1) = fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1
name: Associates.dvd_eq_le
docString: This theorem states that for any type `Œ±` that is a commutative monoid, the "divides" relation (`x` divides `x_1`) is equivalent to the "less than or equal to" relation (`x` is less than or equal to `x_1`). In other words, for any two elements in a commutative monoid, saying that one element divides the other is the same as saying that the one element is less than or equal to the other.

Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `Œ¥ > 0`,
there exists `Œ∑` such that two functions bounded by `Œ∑` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `Œ¥`. One
could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} (E : Type u_2) {m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±) [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  (p : ENNReal) {Œ¥ : ENNReal},
  Œ¥ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ Œ∑,
      0 < Œ∑ ‚àß
        ‚àÄ (f g : Œ± ‚Üí E),
          MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable f Œº ‚Üí
            MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
              MeasureTheory.snorm f p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm g p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm (f + g) p Œº < Œ¥
name: MeasureTheory.exists_Lp_half
docString:
Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `Œ¥ > 0`,
there exists `Œ∑` such that two functions bounded by `Œ∑` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `Œ¥`. One
could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

Let `M` be a smooth œÉ-compact manifold with a metric. Let `K : Œπ ‚Üí Set M` be a locally finite
family of closed sets, let `U : Œπ ‚Üí Set M` be a family of open sets such that `K i ‚äÜ U i` for all
`i`. Then there exists a positive smooth function `Œ¥ : M ‚Üí ‚Ñù‚â•0` such that for any `i` and `x ‚àà K i`,
we have `Metric.closedBall x (Œ¥ x) ‚äÜ U i`.

docString:

Let `{x | p x}` be a subsemigroup of a commutative monoid `M`. Let `f : M ‚Üí N` be a map
such that `f 1 = 1` and `f` is submultiplicative on `{x | p x}`, i.e.,
`p x ‚Üí p y ‚Üí f (x * y) ‚â§ f x * f y`. Let `g i`, `i ‚àà s`, be a finite family of elements of `M` such
that `‚àÄ i ‚àà s, p (g i)`. Then `f (‚àè i in s, g i) ‚â§ ‚àè i in s, f (g i)`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} {N : Type u_5} [inst : CommMonoid M] [inst_1 : OrderedCommMonoid N] (f : M ‚Üí N)
  (p : M ‚Üí Prop),
  f 1 = 1 ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ (x y : M), p x ‚Üí p y ‚Üí f (x * y) ‚â§ f x * f y) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (x y : M), p x ‚Üí p y ‚Üí p (x * y)) ‚Üí
        ‚àÄ (g : Œπ ‚Üí M) {s : Finset Œπ},
          (‚àÄ i ‚àà s, p (g i)) ‚Üí f (Finset.prod s fun i => g i) ‚â§ Finset.prod s fun i => f (g i)
name: Finset.le_prod_of_submultiplicative_on_pred
docString:
Let `{x | p x}` be a subsemigroup of a commutative monoid `M`. Let `f : M ‚Üí N` be a map
such that `f 1 = 1` and `f` is submultiplicative on `{x | p x}`, i.e.,
`p x ‚Üí p y ‚Üí f (x * y) ‚â§ f x * f y`. Let `g i`, `i ‚àà s`, be a finite family of elements of `M` such
that `‚àÄ i ‚àà s, p (g i)`. Then `f (‚àè i in s, g i) ‚â§ ‚àè i in s, f (g i)`.
